comments.commentBody: I recall taking a college course in Asian studies and clearly remember there was a time when the Chinese wealthy would hire workers to till the soil, plant and and tend their crops, and then harvest the fruits and vegetables. The wealthy would rather use humans to do much of the work rather than animals. Why? Because when the crops were harvested, the wealthy would let the workers go. With animals, you have to feed them through the winter. Not much has changed since then, has it? Temporary workers are let go as soon as the job is done. One solution is to have companies who hire temps provide the same benefits as full time employees. Either that, or implement universal healthcare and universal social security/medicare.
This "reform" simply replaces chattel slavery with wage slavery.  After the reformation period in the US south, most blacks were disenfranchised and re-enslaved in various ways.

This was an argument being hotly debated when I was in school: that the Southern plantation owners could have made much more money if they had freed their slaves and paid subsistence wages. Several young historians had used the (then) new-fangled 'computers' to do econometric analyses that clearly showed huge gains in profit from using free labour v. what the plantations had been earning using slave labour.

Of course, most of the older, traditional historians said 'computers' and 'econometrics' (whatever that was) had no place in real, proper history.

And that 150+ year-old argument is still going strong.

Thank you Dr. Walaszek for some common sense. This article and many of the comments are over focused on the possibility that a practitioner might label a person as ill, as if that was a matter of opinion. The plain truth is that sufferers come to us. Thhey know they're ill. They know they don't want to suffer further. Whereas, it can be palliative to a degree, to normalize their pain (ie; explaining the average course of grief), often that's not enough. Many of these comments seem to assert that the lion share of pain is coming from a belief on the part of the sufferer that they ought not be in pain. Hence they are abnormal. This is ridiculous. The pain of depression is as real as the pain of a toothache. Its not anyone's (psychiatrist, philosopher, etc...) job to judge the validity of that pain based on prevalence, causation, social values, etc... The job's to fix it. Period.

I am a geriatric psychiatrist. This means that I regularly care for people who are grieving: grieving the loss of a spouse, of friends, of their careers, of their health, of their ability to care for themselves. They are sad, scared or lonely - and they come to a physician because they are suffering and they hope to feel better. The path to getting better sometimes involves time and patience, sometimes medications, sometimes talk therapy, sometimes exercise, and often combinations of these things.

Removing the bereavement exclusion from the diagnosis of major depressive disorder will not change any of this. People with major depression benefit from treatment, whether or not the depression arises after the death of a loved one. The hazard of pathologizing a normal process is far less serious than the cruelty of not offering help to those who are suffering.

The real problem with USPS is that it offers pernicious incentives. It makes advertising circulars super cheap, and continually increases the costs and cuts services for first class and media rate shipping. Decades of pursuing this policy has put USPS in a bind: If they jack up advertising rates, then they'll lose their remaining customer base. However, if they don't do this, then they're just a glorified (and state subsidized) marketing agency that becomes gradually less relevant for the socially desirable purposes of sending letters and facilitating the expression of ideas through shipping books and magazines.

I know that I'd vote to heavily subsidize USPS if, as a company, it had the moral high ground by continuing to focus on its public mission. But the fact that they've become an arm of the direct mail advertising industry gives me pause. I'm still reluctant to say "let it burn" because I don't want to see the agency's employees, who are innocent in all of this, lose their jobs. But from the point of view of society at large, USPS either need to double down on its actual purpose and receive government support, or else it needs to completely privatize and try to use its direct mail advertising market dominance to expand into other shipping services.

Bulk mail actually subsidizes first-class mail, not the other way around. That's because bulk mail is delivered by the sender already pre-sorted, pre-paid, & barcoded, which means far less work for the post office - and that's why it's cheaper. Nevertheless, first class mail gets prefered, expedited handling.

I'm glad you appreciate how your business benefits from the USPS which provides great service at low rates. But get your facts straight: bulk mail helps make that possible.

@Jeff K: The USPS borrowing authority is capped at a total of 15 billion dollars, this hardly represents a copious amount of taxpayer dollars.
However, your tax dollars subsidize the rate reductions for non-profit mailers; this is known as revenue forgone.

Additionally, to those who state that private companies charge enormous prices to deliver documents; these companies are prohibited by the private express statutes from delivering anything but time sensitive "urgent" mail and charging any less than $3 or twice the applicable rate for 1st class mail, including priority mail, whichever is greater.

Further, the USPS does not deliver to every address in the US, there are still large sections of the country where customers must pick up their mail at a post office.

I agree, the USPS should be subsidized. But that wouldn't even be necessary if it weren't for the 2006 Congressional act requiring the USPS to pre-fund 75 years worth of its employee health & pension benefits - a totally unreasonable burden placed on no other business or public agency.

If the USPS were a company, it never would have been required to pre-fund 75 years of its employees retirement benefits within 10 years, as the USPS was forced to do by Congress in 2006. Any company that had to do that would have declared bankruptcy immediately.

If USPS were a company, it would have had high-priced lobbyists to stop such a ridiculous requirement in the first place. And maybe those congressmen who passed that act - to line their own pockets at the expense of We The People - would be in jail. Where they belong.

If the USPS were a company, it would be UPS or Fed Ex - & charge you $20 to mail a letter from Brooklyn to Manhattan - & probably $40 to mail it to Los Angeles. Unless of course, you live in an "unprofitable" neighborhood, in which case, they won't bother with you at all.
